plist.p: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to BCE's First Quarter 2012 Results Conference Call. I would now like to turn the meeting over to Mr. Thane Fotopoulos. Please go ahead.

Thank you, Jenny. Good morning, everybody. Joining me as usual today I have Bell's President and CEO George Cope as well as Siim Vanaselja, our CFO. Our call this morning will focus on BCE's first quarter results that we announced earlier this morning. Our usually supplementary information package as well as our slide presentation can be found on our corporate BCE website.

Following the review of the slide presentation, George and Siim (00:37) we'll move to Q&A. However, I want to caution that because of our AGM this morning that'll take place right after the call at 9.30, we must end the call at or shortly before 9:00 a.m. this morning.

However, before we begin, I want to remind you that today's remarks will contain certain forward-looking statements with respect to items such as revenue, EBITDA, adjusted EPS, free cash flow and capital intensity. Several assumptions were made by us in preparing these forward-looking statements, and there are risks that our actual results will differ materially from those contemplated by our forward-looking statements.

For additional information on such risks and assumptions, please consult BCE's 2011 Annual MD&A as updated in BCE's 2012 Q1 MD&A and BCE's press release dated May 3, 2012 announcing our financial results for the first quarter of 2012 all filed with the Canadian Securities Commission and with the SEC and which are also available on BCE's website.

Any forward-looking statements may represent BCE's expectations as of today and, accordingly, are subject to change after such date. Except as may be required by Canadian Securities Laws, we do not undertake any obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statement whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise, and I'm making this cautionary statement on behalf of both George and Siim, whose remarks today will contain certain forward-looking statements.
On that note, I'll hand it over to George.
Great. Thanks, Thane. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. I'm going to begin on Slide 4 and start with Wireless and then review some points.

In terms of our Wireless results, really a very strong quarter for the company, most importantly, all the key financial metrics are moving in the right direction. Our net adds of 63,000 on postpaid, although down year over year was a much better mix of postpaid clients. We continue to target our objective of 33%-plus incumbent market share. And as noted, our postpaid smartphone mix is now at 52% and, importantly, that means we have 48% to migrate through and we continue to see higher ARPU from clients who migrate to smartphones.

Our postpaid and our over postpaid focus is driving the ARPU growth. We saw data revenue growth of 31%, and with our blended ARPU up 4.2% year over year, our focus in terms of the postpaid market continues to pay off significantly for us. Importantly also, is our business subscriber base and our strategy of improving our performance in Western Canada, is beginning to pay dividends. As you can see, both those bases up nicely year over year on this slide.

Importantly, as well, is we have begun to see a reduction in our postpaid churn, 1.35% in Q1 versus 1.41% last year. And we found in March the churn was better, was the best month of those three months in the quarter and we anticipate some improvement as we go into Q2 as well.

The net new entrant ports have reduced significantly over the last year on a year-over-year basis. We're not on par yet with the new entrants, but interestingly enough in some cases we are. So that impact on our churn has begun to be positive for us.

Our investment in retention at approximately 10% of service revenue is obviously paying dividends and allowing us to see significant flow-through now from an EBITDA perspective where it was our best EBITDA growth quarter, first quarter in over five years. And importantly, with the strong results, we were also able to grow our margins to 42.9% of service revenue. So all in all, the focus on postpaid's driving the strong Wireless EBITDA results, and from a Wireless perspective, I don't think it gets better than this than what we were able to achieve this quarter in terms of our metrics. So we're really pleased with the quarter.

On Page 5, turning to the Wireline data side, Fibe TV has begun to gain significant traction with 33,000 net adds in the first quarter. Fibe TV ARPU up 21% year over year at $60, and ARPU will continue to grow as we go through the acquisition promotions which are really generally six-month priced discounts. Those will flow through over the coming, obviously, 12 months and even help further from a revenue perspective.

Interestingly enough, 86% of our Fibe customers are taking all three of our products. The launch in Québec City Fibe is only going to enhance our market growth from an IPTV perspective. TV net adds in total were up year over year and came in at 18,000, and that really is a result that satellite has been impacted by IPTV roll-outs of some of the other telco's cable conversion offers which have been aggressive. And also, in our numbers of course, are some migrations from satellite to IPTV, so we see that and we think we'll continue to see part of that as we successfully grow the Fibe business.

In terms of Internet adds, stable year over year; obviously an improvement from Q4, continue to see most of our net adds on the Internet side coming from the pull-through of Fibe TV. So that's positive as we continue to expand the Fibe TV footprint. Residential ARPU on Internet was up and 100%, interestingly, of our net adds in the Internet side are now coming in our FTTN footprint and we continue to grow that footprint as well.

Overall, data revenues now include our TV revenue as of Q1. That aligns with our peers, both in Canada and the U.S., and you can see on a year-over-year basis, our data revenue is really up essentially 1% when you normalize for the fact that the portal revenue's been reclassified in Bell Media.

In terms of Slide 6, our Wireline product, I would say, was a stable year-over-year quarter in terms of Wireline losses in terms of units. Obviously, the base is smaller so the percentage of losses are higher. Really what we're seeing there is continual growth in wireless substitution. I think you can see that in some of the results of our cable competitors where, really, their phone base, particularly in Ontario didn't grow and ours declined. So clearly, that's a matter of wireless substitution.

Overall, the Voice revenue declined as a combination of a 6% reduction in our NAS, and at the same time, seeing reprice in the marketplace in some of the business areas. And particularly last year, we were very successful on attracting global LD minutes, and that revenue would be in our numbers this year, but of course the decline year over year now just reflects what we're seeing on the consumer and normal business markets. And so those are some of the things that have driven the Wireline Voice in the quarter.

Turning to Page 7, in terms of our Media business, really a solid quarter. Revenue on a year-over-year basis is actually up 3%, and the EBITDA of that division, if you exclude the purchase price adjustment which I think everyone knows is a noncash charge, is actually up 13% year over year in the quarter. Generally, what we saw was a softer advertising market on the conventional TV side while specialty TV and Radio held steady, and Radio was actually up year over year.

On the Specialty Programming, rate increases have flowed through and helped contribute to our growth. We do have remaining agreements with a number of major carriers, still. Some of those have been in front of the CRTC. At some point this year, those will be settled and those will flow through our revenue and our EBITDA.

The Astral acquisition, as well, is on track. As everyone knows, it broadens our French content significantly and, if you will, is a perfect complement to the assets we have on the CTV side. Also from a mix perspective, Astral has a stronger mix of subscriber fees and less reliant on advertising, so overall that will help the business as well. The Astral shareholder meeting is scheduled for May 24, and we're in the process right now of getting regulatory approvals and we expect closing in the latter half of 2012.

Overall, we continue to manage the business on a consolidated EBITDA basis. EBITDA was up 1.3% excluding the Media business, and as I've said, driven by, we think, our excellent Wireless results. From the Wireline perspective, we maintained our margins in the challenging part of the Voice environment with that asset. Fibe TV is now clearly gaining traction.

Our business results are actually a little better than we had anticipated, so there is some stability there that we're beginning to see. And most importantly, our operating costs were down $52 million year over year to help offset some of the revenue decline and investments we need to make in Fibe TV.

Overall, we had a reduction in the team count at Bell of about 950 people in the first quarter versus the fourth quarter, and that's across both the Wireless and the Wireline business. And as I mentioned, the Media business continues to contribute significantly to EBITDA and cash flow growth and Astral will only help that as we go forward.
So with that, let me turn it over to Siim. Thank you.
Thanks, George, and good morning to everyone on the call.

I'll begin with a quick summary of our financial results on Slide 10 of the deck. Our execution in the first quarter, I'm happy to say, demonstrated a solid start for the year highlighted by strong Wireless performance, stabilizing business markets performance, some ongoing promotional discounting in the residential marketplace and Media results that delivered a strong contribution to earnings and free cash flow.

Total revenue growth at Bell was 11.6%. That reflects a final quarter of incremental revenue contribution from the acquisition of CTV which, as you know, we began reporting in the Bell Media segment starting in the second quarter of 2011. Excluding Bell Media, Bell's revenues were essentially unchanged year over year, but I would say that if normalizing for the reclassification of our Portal business to Bell Media, Bell revenues excluding CTV, actually increased about 1%.

EBITDA was up 6.6% in the quarter. Excluding Bell Media, Bell's EBITDA increased 1.3% and that was driven by the standout Wireless EBITDA growth that we experienced of 13% and that was achieved while activating a higher volume of smartphones year over year. So we anticipate having captured greater than 1/3 market share of incumbent postpaid subscribers in the quarter.

CapEx accelerated this quarter. That was on continued broadband fiber deployment and network conditioning and support of IPTV. Also, Wireless spending increased year over year with the ongoing build-out of our 4G LTE wireless network in urban markets.

In the quarter, we generated higher year-over-year net earnings and a significant increase in free cash flow, which together with our strong balance sheet, supports the ongoing execution of our business plan and capital structure objectives for 2012.

Adjusted EPS increased $0.03 per share over last year to $0.75. In addition to the contribution from higher year-over-year EBITDA, the adjusted EPS improvement was from lower net pension financing costs and a reduction in the Federal statutory tax rate for 2012.

We generated free cash flow of $327 million for the quarter, that was on track with our plan, and $62 million higher year over year. And that increase was driven primarily by higher EBITDA, and as well, the one-time customer rebates that were paid in the first quarter of 2011 under Bell's CRTC deferral account obligation.

And finally, our NCIB program for 2012 that we announced last December, which targeted the repurchase of $250 million in BCE common shares, is now completed. It was completed on March 12. And over the past three years, we've repurchased over 62 million BCE shares at a total cost of about $1.7 billion and an average price per share $27.85.

So with that overview, let's turn to the detailed results of our Wireless segment. Wireless service revenues increased 6% on 8.1% postpaid revenue growth, and as George mentioned, this reflects the higher mix of postpaid customers in higher APRU geographies as well as a higher market share of business customers. Smartphone subscribers now represent 52% of our postpaid base, up from 34% a year ago, and that drove data revenue growth of 31% in the quarter and contributed to a 4.2% year-over-year increase in APRU.
Wireless product revenues were down a little over 5% on richer competitive offers that drove average handset prices lower across the marketplace.

Wireless EBITDA growth of 13% was a key highlight in the quarter, yielding a revenue flow-through to EBITDA of 87%. That was our best quarter of EBITDA performance since the fourth quarter of 2008 and the highest first quarter EBITDA growth rate in over five years. The improved flow-through resulted in significant margin improvement as well of 2.6 percentage points to 42.9%. So I'd say overall, a very robust quarter of performance for Wireless with great financials backed up by a solid set of Wireless metrics.

I'll turn to Slide 12. Bell's Wireline performance in the quarter showed continuing decline in Voice revenues from ongoing NAS and LD erosion, and the repricing of connectivity services in our business markets unit. The increase in Voice revenue erosion in this quarter was attributable to richer upfront discounts and retention credits on residential service bundles, and that was driven by a higher level of competitive pricing intensity across the market.

Additionally, throughout 2011 we benefited from a strong improvement in the sale of global long distance minutes, as George had mentioned, which is impacting the year-over-year comparison in 2012. It's noteworthy, however, that the rate of decline in overall Wireline revenues improved versus the previous quarter owing to solid TV and residential Internet growth which are both becoming a larger portion of our Wireline revenue mix and, as well, to the stabilizing performance of our business markets unit.

In particular, this quarter showed improved traction in IT business solutions and professional services and higher data sales which showed growth after a number of previous quarters of decline. Although EBITDA decreased 3.9% in Wireline, margins were kept relatively stable year over year at the 39% level and that reflects about a 3.2% reduction in operating expenses from continued cost management initiatives and, particularly, from savings on the labor reductions that were undertaken in 2011.

In the Bell Media segment, subscriber revenue growth was strong in the quarter increasing 30% year over year and that was driven by higher programming rates charged to broadcast distributors on contract renewals primarily for our specialty sports channels and, as well, as from steady growth in mobile TV.

Advertising revenues were down 4% year over year. That was on a softer national ad market in conventional television. Advertising demands remained healthy in radio and in specialty TV, and audience levels and viewership remained strong across our channels.

Media EBITDA in the quarter was $81 million. As I've been highlighting each of the last three quarterly calls, as part of the purchase price accounting for CTV, that EBITDA includes a noncash charge to amortize the fair value step-up in CTV's programming inventory. That charge was $23 million this quarter, and excluding that, Bell Media's EBITDA was up a strong 13% over last year.
Bell Media's performance is certainly meeting all of our expectations both in terms of financial performance and in the strategic opportunities to improve the growth profile of Bell.

On Slide 14, BCE's adjusted EPS was $0.75 per share this quarter, or 4.2% higher than last year. Higher year-over-year EBITDA accounted for $0.09 of that EPS growth. Lower year-over-year net pension financing costs and a 1.8% reduction in the statutory tax rate to 26.4% for 2012 on the lower federal tax rate also contributed to the improvement. Higher year-over-year interest expense and depreciation expense are mainly due to the acquisition of CTV, which overall, is accretive to our earnings.

So the EPS result was slightly ahead of plan for the quarter on a higher-than-forecast level of tax adjustments which are always difficult to forecast. Tax recoveries amounted to $0.03 per share this quarter which were equal to the amount that we experienced in the first quarter last year. And there's no change, however, to our previous guidance of a 23% effective tax rate for the full 2012 year.

Our free cash flow summary is on Slide 15. Cash generation of $327 million in the quarter was on track with plan and 23% higher year over year reflecting EBITDA growth and an improvement in our working capital position given the impact of CRTC-mandated payments to customers in the first quarter of 2011 that I touched on earlier. CapEx spending in the quarter was $165 million higher year over year, and even with that step-up in CapEx spending this quarter, we remained within our 16% capital intensity target.

Two other notable uses of cashes in the quarter that I would mention, the first is cash taxes which increased year over year due to a higher final installment payment made this quarter in respect of the 2011 tax year as well as the incremental contribution from Bell Media. The second is higher severance payments, and that's related to the reduction of about 1,200 management positions in the latter part of 2011. As a result of that downsizing, we should realize approximately $100 million in annualized labor savings going forward.
Our continued strong free cash flow generation provides solid support for BCE's 2012 dividend rate, all supported by the foundation of our strong balance sheet and credit metrics.

And to recap then, we have had a solid start to the year in executing the plans and the guidance that we gave you for the 2012 year. Looking ahead, we foresee no fundamental changes in the outlook of our core businesses, and we remain confident in our ability to execute and grow the overall business.

Although in the first quarter we are seeing some incremental pressure on Wireline margins from the impacts of growing our Fibe TV customer base and from year-over-year Voice revenue decline, at the same time we're also seeing improved Wireless profitability even as we continue to capture a higher share of smartphone additions and Wireless customers in Western Canada and in business markets. So on balance, I'd say we continue to expect Bell's EBITDA margin overall for 2012 to be stable year over year excluding Media.

Lastly, our pending acquisition of Astral should also be accretive to our overall earnings and free cash flow as we move into 2013 when that transaction is closed. So all in all, we're excited about our future and believe we should be in a good position to continue executing on our dividend growth objectives.
And with that, thanks, everyone, for joining the call. I'll turn the call back over to Thane and the operator to open up for questions.

Okay. Great. So before we do start, I want to remind everybody, given our time constraints this morning, to please keep their questions short to the point and limited to just one and maybe one brief follow-up so we can get to as many of you as possible or in the queue. Jenny, we're ready to proceed.
Thank you, sir. [Operator Instruction] Our first question is from Maher Yaghi from Desjardins Capital. Please go ahead.

Yes. Thank you for taking my questions. I just wanted to ask you on the Wireless side, I was quite surprised by seeing your usage per subscriber going up from 256 minutes to 285 minutes in the quarter. Can you maybe talk a little bit about what's driving this higher usage in Wireless? And on the ARPU, of the 4.2% increase in ARPU, how much of that is because of your prepaid has declined year on year? I mean, I'm just trying to understand what's driving this increase. Is it mainly on the back of postpaid ARPU increases or the mix is helping the ARPU increase?

Sure. So thank you. On the usage, it really would be the growth in our overall postpaid base and also the continued growth we're seeing on the business side in winning back some market share of business we would have lost a number of years ago when we didn't have things like global roaming, et cetera. So I think that's driving it.

In terms of our overall ARPU, we're, as you know, trying to now report the mixed ARPU only. But to help answer the questions for the analysts, both our postpaid and prepaid ARPU were up year over year. But at the same time, because we're doing more postpaid, the overall mix has helped as well. To give you a little more color, you saw our data revenue growth, our Voice ARPU was down about 4.9% a year and the data growth you'll see in what we reported. So hopefully that'll help all the analysts get a sense of where we were in total.
Okay. Thank you.
Thank you. Following question is from Phillip Huang from UBS. Please go ahead.

Yeah. Thanks. Good morning. I wanted to touch on something that George mentioned earlier. Given your Fibe TV footprint is so rapidly expanding, can you maybe talk a bit about when we could look forward to a reversal of the dilutive effects to ARPU and margins from the current six-month acquisition promo on Fibe. I believe in Telus' case, they had said it would be around 500,000 subscriber mark. I'm just wondering if that's a similar benchmark that we should use.

I can't really comment on what our competitor would have said. What I would say is one of the things we did change, we've tried to go from 12-month promotions to six-month promotions. And the real reason we're doing that is we're finding, and I think people would get it, from a customer perspective, after 12 months, it feels much less like a promotion and more like a rate plan and so it becomes much more expensive at the call center in terms of customers calling in in month 13 because in fairness they've forgotten they had a 12-month promotion. So we're trying to frontend load as much of the discounts in a six-month basis a little more like the Wireless model. The Wireless has never had 12-month type of promotions before. So that's we have been trying to do.

In terms of the ARPU flow-through, we definitely will see a maturing of the IPTV base after the six months and that helps. But it's a growth, to your point, of IPTV subs. The pace of that, of course, has some impact.

But overall, the most important part for us in the quarter is in the territories where we had IPTV, we are actually RGU positive for the quarter and we see the footprint growth, as we say, we're going to go from the 2 million to the 3.3 million at the end of this year. All of that, we think, bodes well for us in terms of getting the Wireline, as we go through that continual challenge on Wireline, that adds a way to help moderate that with the growth on the IPTV. Hopefully that's helpful.
Yeah. Thank you.
Thank you. The following question is from Greg MacDonald from Macquarie Securities. Please go ahead.

Thanks. Good morning, guys. Big postpaid versus prepaid mix over the last couple of years, a big change in that mix and it was evidenced, I think, this morning, George, when you were talking about the 8% postpaid revenue growth relative to the 6% overall. I'm guessing this is positive for EBITDA because the EBITDA margin this quarter surprisingly a bit to the upside, and I know 1Q is the strongest Q for margin. I know there are a lot of moving parts. But I wonder if you just might comment directionally what's the normalized margin outlook for the business based on where the postpaid mix is going? Is it 39%, 40%? I mean, I don't know others, but that's kind of what I've been looking at, or is it more for 43% – what you're showing currently in the 1Q?

Yeah, so a lot behind the question, so I'll try to keep it brief. I think what I would say is it's very clear, and you're right, where our focus is on the postpaid side, from a distribution perspective we believe to need to be in prepaid segment. I've struggled for my 20 years in the industry to understand whether or not anyone's making money in the prepaid space at the ARPUs that we see so why our focus is on postpaid. We see that's where the value for our shareholders is.

In terms of our margin, I think, Siim tried to touch, and I want to be careful of giving margin guidance, but I think it would be fair to say that we think with the postpaid mix we're seeing that an overall margin on service revenue north of 40% for 2012 we think would be something we would like to see happen, if that's helpful a little bit for everyone.

And I think, as Siim said, I think it's probably fair to say we now believe Wireless margins will be a little stronger than we may have anticipated in October, November. Wireline margins impacted a little more because of IPTV growth, but on balance, I think as Siim would say, we expect the margins to be stable year over year excluding, of course, the Media business which is great free cash flow but generates, as everyone knows, a lower EBITDA margin.

Just a quick follow-on. Thanks for that. Just a quick follow- on. What's contributing to the stronger margin outlook for Wireless? Is it cost on devices that are, let's call them, non-iPhone devices or where is the industry standing right now on flowing that potential cost benefit to the consumer?

Well, we struggle with the concept that we're going to see any significant reductions there just because of the success of particular smartphone brands that we're seeing. For us, it's mix and it's also an incredible discipline in our organization on cost. I mean, our employee resources on the mobility business were 500 people less at the end of Q1 than at the end of Q4.

I mean, we are driving costs across our organization culturally, not just in the Wireline business. And so that with the mix of postpaid and, I think, most important, Greg, is the growth in ARPU, right, and the reduction in churn. And if we continue to see the growth in ARPU and some stabilization or improvement in churn, that, as everyone knows on the line, is when the model really flows and that's what we hope will happen and, therefore, no guarantees. But that's why we're thinking margins may be a little better than 40%.
Thanks a lot, George.
Thanks.
Thank you. The following questions is from Jeff Fan from Scotia Capital. Please go ahead.

Yes, thanks very much and good morning. My question is on the Wireline side. Early this year, I believe, you guys put through some price increases on the Wireline businesses on the residential side. I'm wondering if you can just talk around the (31:35). You have price increases and your margin was stable in the quarter. Going forward, unless we see more price increases, I'm just wondering what your assumptions are behind keeping Wireline margins stable going forward? Is it all coming through cost cuts?

Yeah, it's a good question. I think it's fair to say you're right. There were price increases in the marketplace on our side in the first quarter. Based on a number of announcements from competitors, we anticipate price increases from them in the second quarter, and from one sense, that should help us from a subscriber perspective in the marketplace keeping us competitive.

I think it's fair to say that some of the aggressive promotions we've seen really generally I believe offset the price increases if you really look through our numbers. And so that's why what we really tried to say is we think the Wireline margins are clearly a little bit less than what would have been expected, and I think it's fair to say the Wireless are a little better. And so we're trying to do, without getting into specific guidance on two margins, our outlook is the same. Our guidance is the same, and we think our Wireless and Wireline margin combined will be stable year over year. Becase, you know, it is moving parts here. Growth in IPTV. You had better margins in Wireless is what we want to see happen and that's how we're managing the businesses. And I keep telling in every meeting with investors, we are managing the company on a consolidated EBITDA basis. We have to do that to drive the dividend growth.
Thanks.
Thank you. The following question is from Drew McReynolds from RBC Capital Markets. Please go ahead.

Yeah. Thanks very much. Good morning. Just a question on the net TV sub adds when you get your Satellite business. Can you just give some additional commentary on satellite migration versus the intensifying cable competition? As you roll out the IPTV footprint, do you think the migration rate, or call it, cannibalization rate, stays stable? And a follow-up question for Siim just on the NCIB or share repurchases going forward. If you're not doing voluntary pension contributions, just where does share buyback fit in your free cash flow priorities? Thank you.

Sure. Let me handle the first one. I think stable on satellites, a harder one for us to actually know as it rolls out. There's definitely an early propensity of people who have been Bell customers knowing we have this great new leading technology, of course, asking. Many of those are on satellite services. But in terms of our migration numbers, if the analysts assume a 15% to 20% of our IPTV over time, that might be a safe number to use and we're learning as we go here. But overall, we're obviously thrilled with the growth because it's also the pull-through we're getting on the Internet and the NAS. But something in that range might be a reasonable number, and we'll try to update people every quarter as we go through this process.

And with respect to your question on share buybacks, those are certainly an objective within our capital structure objectives for the company. For 2012, we've completed the $250 million in the first quarter that we've been targeting with the announced acquisitions of MLSE and the pending closing of that, the closing of the acquisition of Astral later in the year.

We will be using our surplus free cash flow post common dividends towards those acquisitions. So there won't be further buybacks through the course of 2012. We will look at our surplus cash objectives then and priorities for 2013 and provide our guidance early in 2013 on that.
Thank you.

I just want to add something. Thane has said to me, I thought I said one thing, and he tells me I said the other. On the satellite, I would think the analysts should be using 15% to 20%. If I said 10% to 15%, I apologize. I thought I had actually said 15% to 20% on the satellite versus IPTV. We think that's a reasonable outlook as we go forward and we will update as we can every quarter on that.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Thank you. The following question is from Vince Valentini from TD Securities. Please go ahead.
Hi. Thanks. I think you did say 15% to 20%, but I got to tell you, I'm not sure what that means. Are you saying that 15% to 20% of your DTH base will switch to IPTV over time?

Yeah, what we're saying is if you look at what we're seeing on – and look, we're going through this as we see it. It's accretive because of the pull-through of the Internet. But if we look at the previous quarter and what's been happening, we think at the moment it's reasonable to assume if we add 40,000 IPTV subs in a quarter, we're thinking we may get anywhere from 15% to 20% of those migrating from satellite.

Okay. That makes sense. My first question is really on the Media side. This battle you're having on the subscription fees, it seems like all of the integrated carriers who own content have agreed to the rate increases that TSN and others were charging when all the others, we call them independents, haven't. Is the worst case scenario here, depending on this sort of regulatory battle, that you get the same rate increase from all the independents that you got from the integrateds, and in a better case scenario, you get even more? Or is it possibly you get even a lower rate increase for the next round of BDUs than you got from the first round?

Yeah. Well, first of all, we have settled actually with many who are not in the vertical integrated part of the industry. But you are right. There are some major players who aren't vertically integrated who, well a lot of this issue has surrounded. We were quite encouraged by the recent CRTC direction which recognized the fact that anything that happens here will be retroactive rates at the beginning of these discussions. And so we would anticipate that given that the volume of business we do with some of the suppliers we've already – some of our customers we've already made agreements with that these are the companies who are smaller would obviously not get prices below what other larger players would see.

We'll see how all of this unfolds. As we look at it from our organization perspective, we're unable to accrue any of those revenues obviously until we settle those arrangements. When we settle those arrangements, they'll flow into our revenue over the coming three, four years and we'll come back with an update when we get those settled.
Okay. Thanks.
Thank you. The following question is from Glen Campbell from Merrill Lynch. Please go ahead.

Yes. Thanks very much. Wireless retention spending was very low, as you mentioned. We're seeing a lot of the U.S. operators were getting up to 70% or 80% of handsets sold now being smartphones. I wonder if you could give us that figure for Bell, and if not, could you give us a sense of whether you're at a stable level now or whether you expect the mix to continue to move towards smartphones and whether there are likewise whether you think the replacement rate is now at a fairly stable level or whether there's upside risk? Thanks.

Hey, Glen, I don't have the number at the top of my head, so if I misquote, Thane will come back to you on that. But I mean, literally more than 100% of our net adds are smartphones. Almost all of our upgrades are smartphones. For us, we're just working through the base. I think actually, our base of smartphones might be even a little higher than some of the bigger U.S. carriers. Again, I might be off a little bit, but it's pretty close.

And so we just continue every – we went from low 30s last year to 50 now and it would seem to me that type of pace, Glen, should continue if not accelerate. And we continue to see an improvement in ARPU when people move from voice-only products to smartphone products, obviously not at the rate of the early adopters because they were the heaviest users, but it is ARPU accretive for us. But look, to give you the exact numbers, I'm happy to have Thane afterwards take offline and talk you through it.
Okay, great. Thank you.
Thank you. The following question is from Adam Shine from National Bank Financial. Please go ahead.

Hi. Thanks a lot. Good morning. George, I don't want you to give away any secrets obviously on the IPTV front. But you've started expanding beyond the core Toronto and Montreal regions, and you've started to see some better traction on IPTV in Q1. Can you give us a sense as to maybe where the traction is being seen?
